name: Overburden removal; Surface coal mine
description:
This process is part of the NETL Unit Process Library.  To access the library and the original dataset:
1) Navigate to the NETL LCA home page (http://www.netl.doe.gov/lca)
2) Then navigate to the “Unit Process Library” 
3) From the library, the unit process of interest can be found either through the "Complete Listing of the Unit Process Library link" or through the link to the "Unit Process Database" spreadsheet
4) For each process, a Data Sheet (DS) and Data File (DF) are available

BRIEF DESCRIPTION
This parameterized unit process provides a summary of relevant input and output flows associated with the removal of overburden from a surface mine. This includes the amount of electricity and fuel required to power equipment and the direct particulate matter (PM) and volatile organic compound (VOC) emissions from operating equipment and using explosives. Combustion emissions are not included in this unit process.


MODELING NOTE
In the DS file, this unit process is one of three mining stages grouped into a single proces entitled, "Surface Coal Mining – Overburden Removal, Extraction, and Reclamation".  The metadata below reflects the Goal and Scope, Boundary and Description, and Citation and Associated Documentation of all three mining stages within the combined process.

GOAL AND SCOPE
This unit process provides a summary of relevant input and output flows associated with the extraction of coal from a surface mine. This includes the amount of electricity and fuel required to power equipment and the direct particulate matter (PM) and volatile organic compound (VOC) emissions from operating equipment and using explosives. Combustion emissions are not included in this unit process. The reference flow of this unit process is: 1 kg of coal.

Note: This process deviates from the DS in that it uses the input "Ammonia, steam reforming, liquid, at plant" in place of "Ammonium nitrate".  The input value for ammonia reflects the amount of ammonia necessary to produce the required quantity of ammonium nitrate for this process.


BOUNDARY AND DESCRIPTION
A visual representation of the boundary of this unit process is available in the associated documentation (referenced in the Citation and Associated Documentation section below). 	This UP is parameterized into mining stages: Overburden removal, coal extraction, and mine reclamation. This UP is based on a reference Western mine. A strip ratio from any mine can be applied to scale the impacts of the overburden removal scenario. The reference strip ratio is 5:1 and represents a reference Western mine. This UP has a diesel scalar and electricity switch to account for mines that use all diesel equipment (e.g., Indonesia).

For energy calculations, the mining equipment was separated into electrically powered equipment and diesel powered equipment. For all calculations, the equipment was separated into mining stage: overburden removal, coal extraction, and mine reclamation.

The diesel requirements were calculated using the Energy and Environmental Profile of the U.S. Mining Industry developed by the U.S. Department of Energy’s Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy division and the National Mining Association (U.S. Department of Energy and National Mining Association, n.d.).  Chapter Two of the source focused on coal; description of coal types, overview of coal mining, energy requirements for underground and surface mines, and emissions from coal mining.  The data source provides energy data for specific mining activities such as coal handling, extraction, and grinding.  BCS, Incorporated (BCS) developed the data by integrating the U.S. Department of Energy’s Energy Information Administration’s 1997 Coal Industry data into the Western Mining Engineering, Inc.’s SHERPA Mine Cost Software to create 2002 estimates.  BCS also used Mine and Mill Equipment Cost, An Estimator’s Guide to develop the data.  Newer data for specific coal mining processes are not available.  This unit process parameterizes key variables to allow for evaluation of data uncertainty when used in a life cycle model.

The reference flow for this unit process is one kg of coal.  To calculate the amount of diesel needed, the sum of the equipment’s energy requirements, in Btu per ton, was divided by the appropriate conversion to convert tons to kg and then divided by the high heating value of diesel (U.S. Energy Information Administration, 2011), in Btu per kg, to obtain the diesel requirement in kg of diesel per kg of coal.  

To calculate the amount of ammonium nitrate and fuel oil (ANFO) used to excavate coal, 1994 data specific to the Powder River Basin (PRB) was used (Stump, B., 1995).  The average weight percentages for the composition of ANFO were taken from an ANFO material safety data sheet (Maxam North America, 2010).  The amount of ammonium nitrate was calculated by multiplying the kg of ANFO per coal produced by the average weight percent of ammonium nitrate.  The kg of ANFO per coal produced was multiplied by the average weight percent of light fuel oil to calculate the amount of light fuel oil in kg fuel oil per kg of coal.  Particulate matter (PM) and volatile organic compounds (VOCs) are emitted during coal extraction from an underground mine.  To calculate the amount of VOC emissions released during the excavation of coal, 1989-1998 data specific to the PRB (McVehil, G.E., 2001) and 2011 coal production data by the National Mining Association (National Mining Association, 2012) was used. The amount of VOCs released, in tons per year, was multiplied by the appropriate conversion and divided by the amount of coal produced, which was also multiplied by the appropriate conversions, to obtain the kg of VOC per kg of coal.  The VOC emissions were calculated for the coal types of bituminous, subbituminous, and lignite by using the calculation just described above but replacing the coal produced with the appropriate coal type production value.  It was assumed the VOC emissions released were for one year.

The PM emissions were calculated using the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency’s AP 42 (U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, 2009).  Chapter 11.9 of the source focused on Western surface coal which included emission factor equations and scaling factors.  Other factors that were incorporated into these equations, such as coal moisture content, were obtained from a 2012 U.S. Department of Energy document (U.S. Department of Energy, 2012) and a Caterpillar, Inc. equipment specification (Caterpillar).  The PM emissions were broken down into extraction processes such as blasting, truck loading, bulldozing, etc.  Emission factor equations and conversions were used to calculate the amount of PM emissions based on the reference flow of one kg of coal.  Where applicable, the moisture content of coal was used to calculate PM emissions for the coal types of bituminous, subbituminous, and lignite.  To obtain the emissions for PM10 and PM2.5, the scaling factor pertaining to each emission was multiplied by the amount of PM emissions per unit of coal for both PM10 and PM25.  It was assumed that PM data not pertaining to coal types was calculated for a surface mine only.  For the bulldozer, it was assumed that the equipment operated for 12 hours per day.  A five miles per hour grading speed and 20 year lifetime of coal mine for existing mines was assumed in the calculation of the PM emissions for grading.  To calculate the unmitigated PM emissions, the sum of the PM10 and PM2.5 emissions were both multiplied by 15 percent, because it was assumed mitigation measures would reduce emissions by 85 percent.  The ammonium nitrate, electricity, light fuel oil, PM, and VOC requirements were placed as parameters in the DS file, so the items could be adjusted to measure uncertainties.  There are other adjustable parameters such as coal type and moisture content.

Additional details regarding input and output flows, including calculation methods, are contained in the associated documentation (referenced in the Citation and Associated Documentation section below).

This process contains one or more surrogate product flows as replacements for proprietary product flows used in the NETL Unit Process Library.  All surrogate flow were taken from the U.S. Life Cycle Inventory Database; a list of surrogate flows used in this process is provided below:
1) Diesel, at refinery
2) Electricity, at Grid, US, 2010


CITATION AND ASSOCIATED DOCUMENTATION
This dataset should be cited as: 
National Energy Technology Laboratory (NETL). 2015. NETL Life Cycle Inventory Data - Unit Process: Overburden removal; Surface coal mine. U.S. Department of Energy, National Energy Technology Laboratory. Last updated: September 2015 (Version 1). Retrieved on [DATE] from [URL for this dataset].

This dataset is part of the NETL Unit Process Library.  The Library offers additional information concerning this dataset in the form of a Detailed Spreadsheet  Documentation (DS) file and a Process Documentation File (DF).  The DS file  is an Excel file that contains all of the parameters, inputs, and outputs for a given system as well as background data, calculations and quality scores.  The DF file is a PDF document that contains major assumptions and data sources that are the basis for each unit process.  The NETL Unit Process Library is located on the NETL website (netl.doe.gov) under Research / Energy Analysis / Energy Trends and Issues / Life Cycle Analysis / Unit Process Library.

This dataset was converted directly from the DS with additional supporting information provided by the DF.  Full citations for the DS and DF are given below.

DS File
National Energy Technology Laboratory (NETL). 2013. NETL Life Cycle Inventory Data - Unit Process: Surface Coal Mining – Overburden Removal, Extraction, and Reclamation. U.S. Department of Energy, National Energy Technology Laboratory. Last updated: September 2015 (Version 02). Retrieved on 09/29/2015 from: http://www.netl.doe.gov/File%20Library/Research/Energy%20Analysis/Life%20Cycle%20Analysis/UP_Library/DS_Stage1_O_Surface_Coal_Mining_2013-02.xlsx.

DF File
National Energy Technology Laboratory (NETL). 2013. NETL Life Cycle Inventory Data - Unit Process: Surface Coal Mining – Overburden Removal, Extraction, and Reclamation. U.S. Department of Energy, National Energy Technology Laboratory.  Last updated: September 2015 (Version 02). Retrieved on 09/29/2015 from: http://www.netl.doe.gov/File%20Library/Research/Energy%20Analysis/Life%20Cycle%20Analysis/UP_Library/DF_Stage1_O_Surface_Coal_Mining_2013-02.pdf.

category.name: Bit. Coal and Lignite Surface Mining

processDocumentation.timeDescription: This data set is representative of best available public data from 01/01/1989 to 12/31/2011 and is not subject to limited usability within sub-time spans (e.g. summer, winter).
processDocumentation.technologyDescription:
This unit process provides a summary of relevant input and output flows associated with the extraction of coal from a surface mine.  The default parameter settings for this process are based on a reference Western mine; however parameters can be adapted to reflect surface mining in other geographic regions.

A visual representation of the boundary of this unit process is available in the associated documentation (referenced in the Citation and Associated Documentation section of the Description field).
processDocumentation.modelingConstantsDescription: All elementary and technosphere flows are calculated on a functional unit basis. Calculations involving combustion primarily to generate useful work are done using lower heating values (LHV) and calculations involving combustion primarily to generate useful heat are done using higher heating values (HHV). Unless explicitly stated in the associated reference documents applicable calculations assumed standard atmospheric temperature and pressure (SATP).
processDocumentation.restrictionsDescription:
Use of this dataset is not restricted, but a statement of attribution is required. Please use the following attribution statement: 

National Energy Technology Laboratory's (NETL) Unit Process Library
626 Cochrans Mill Road, P.O. Box 10940
Pittsburgh, PA 15236-0940
http://www.netl.doe.gov/research/energy-analysis/life-cycle-analysis/unit-process-library

A. B. Assumes any liability with this report as to its use, or damages resulting from the use of any information, apparatus, method, or process disclosed in this document.

Reference herein to any specific commercial product, process, or service by trade name, trademark, manufacturer, or otherwise, does not necessarily constitute or imply its endorsement, recommendation, or favoring by NETL. The views and opinions of the authors expressed herein do not necessarily state or reflect those of NETL.
processDocumentation.intendedApplication: This is a gate-to-gate extraction process and can be used for any type of LCA study.
processDocumentation.projectDescription: National Energy Technology Laboratory (NETL) Unit Process Library

publication.name: National Energy Technology Laboratory (NETL). 2013. Surface Coal Mining – Overburden Removal, Extraction, and Reclamation

sources.name: National Energy Technology Laboratory (NETL).  2012.  Quality Guidelines for Energy System Studies:  Specifications for Selected Feedstocks
McVehil, G.E.; Addison, E.L.; Baugues, K.A.  2001.  Air Quality and Visibility Impacts of Powder River Basin Coal Mining at Badlands National Park
Stump, B. 1995. Practical Observations of US Mining Practices and Implications for CTBT Monitoring
National Mining Association (NMA). 2012. U.S. Coal Production and Number of Mines by State and Coal Type
U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). 2009a. AP 42, Fifth Edition, Volume I, Chapter 11: Mineral Products Industry, 11.9 Western Surface Coal Mining
U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) and National Mining Association (NMA). 2002. Energy and Environmental Profile of the U.S. Mining Industry:  Chapter 2 Coal
Maxam North America, Inc. 2010. Material Safety Data Sheet, ANFO
National Energy Technology Laboratory (NETL). 2013. Surface Coal Mining – Overburden Removal, Extraction, and Reclamation

parameters.name: NH3_NH4NO3
parameters.description: [kg/kg] Mass of ammonia required to product 1 kg ammonium nitrate

parameters.name: Dies_Eff_Scaler
parameters.description: [dimensionless] Scaler to adjust diesel consumption to account for manual operations at Indonesian mine

parameters.name: Strip_Ratio_Ref
parameters.description: [dimensionless] Ratio of overburden removal to coal extracted for reference mine

parameters.name: NOx_Total
parameters.description: [kg/kg] Mass of NOx emissions per unit of coal produced

parameters.name: PM_25to10
parameters.description: [kg/kg] Mass of total PM2.5 to PM10 emissions per unit of coal produced for reference mine

parameters.name: NH3NO3_Scale
parameters.description: [kg/kg] Mass of ammonium nitrate per unit of coal produced

parameters.name: Diesel_Scale
parameters.description: [kg/kg] Amount of diesel energy input per unit of coal produced

parameters.name: Elec_Switch
parameters.description: [dimensionless] Switch to turn electricity on/off depending on mining country (0 = no elec; 1 = elec)

parameters.name: VOC_Scale
parameters.description: [kg/kg] Mass of VOC emissions per unit of coal produced

parameters.name: VOC_Ref
parameters.description: [kg/kg] Mass of VOC emissions per unit of coal produced for reference mine

parameters.name: OB_Switch
parameters.description: [dimensionless] Switch to turn strip ratio scalar on/off depending on activity type (0 = coal extraction or reclamation; 1 = OB removal)

parameters.name: FO_Ref
parameters.description: [kg/kg] Mass of light fuel oil per unit of coal produced for reference mine

parameters.name: Diesel_EDensity
parameters.description: [MJ/kg diesel] Energy density of diesel taken from the Excel model of NETL's 2008 Petroleum Baseline (http://netl.doe.gov/File%20Library/Research/Energy%20Analysis/Life%20Cycle%20Analysis/PetroBasedFuelsLCGHGAnlys2005BslnModel.xls)

parameters.name: SR_Scaler
parameters.description: [dimensionless] Ratio of strip ratios used to scale inputs and outputs

parameters.name: PM25_Total
parameters.description: [kg/kg] Mass of total PM2.5 emissions per unit of coal produced

parameters.name: NOx
parameters.description: [kg/kg] Mass of NOx emissions from overburden blasting per unit of coal produced

parameters.name: PM25
parameters.description: [kg/kg] Mass of total PM2.5 emissions per unit of coal produced for reference mine

parameters.name: Percent_Mit
parameters.description: [dimensionless] Fraction of PM emissions that are mitigated

parameters.name: Elec_Ref
parameters.description: [MWh/kg] Amount of electricity input per unit of coal produced for reference mine

parameters.name: NH3NO3_Ref
parameters.description: [kg/kg] Mass of ammonium nitrate per unit of coal produced for reference mine

parameters.name: Diesel_Ref
parameters.description: [kg/kg] Amount of diesel energy input per unit of coal produced for reference mine

parameters.name: PM_25to10_Unmit
parameters.description: [kg/kg] Mass of unmitigated PM2.5 to PM10 emissions per unit of coal produced

parameters.name: Elec_Scale
parameters.description: [MWh/kg] Amount of electricity input per unit of coal produced

parameters.name: PM_25to10_Total
parameters.description: [kg/kg] Mass of total PM2.5 to PM10 emissions per unit of coal produced

parameters.name: Diesel_MDensity
parameters.description: [kg/m3] Mass density of diesel.  Source: NETL 2008 Petroleum Baseline

parameters.name: PM25_Unmit
parameters.description: [kg/kg] Mass of unmitigated PM2.5 emissions per unit of coal produced

parameters.name: FO_Scale
parameters.description: [kg/kg] Mass of light fuel oil per unit of coal produced

parameters.name: Strip_Ratio_UI
parameters.description: [dimensionless] Ratio of overburden removal to coal extracted for modeled mine
